comments.commentBody: Like yourself, perhaps.

Hillary had better rest up before the debate, even if it means losing more ground in the polls.  If she starts coughing during the debate Trump will be President.  When she's well she'd better come up with a simple, strong message that will appeal to simple people.

That's brave to say you will "be retiring to another country" if Trump is elected. You can take your Social Security with you, but are you willing to give up the Medicare health benefits you worked and paid for over all those many years?
How many proposals by Pres. Hillary Clinton will not be "doomed to fail" in the GOP-controlled U.S. Senate and U.S. House of Representatives? Pres. Obama can probably give us some idea about that.

The only states that get "more power" from the electoral college are the handful of close states whose electoral votes the candidates have to compete for. All the rest -- small, medium or large -- are roundly ignored by the candidates. And if you live in one of them, you might as well go fishing on election day for all your vote counts. If you're tired of a relic from the 18th century letting that small handful of states decide presidential elections, then Google a proposal called the National Popular Vote Plan.
What's an LV screen?  An octogenarian needs to know!

If it works for you, then great. But many other teenagers either continue eating meat, or return to eating meat after a vegetarian period, and also end up happy and healthy. Vegetarianism is not a "magic bullet" for health, there are many overweight and unhealthy vegetarians.

If your dad had not made the comment, would you have returned to eating meat?

According to Open Secrets, ECMC has paid Podesta Group $580,000 to lobby for them. [7][8][9] The Podesta Group, founded by Tony Podesta and John Podesta is one of the most powerful and influential lobbying firms in Washington, DC. [10]

Oh, and you're own personal experiences in a very specific place are representative, and offer a much better story of the economy?

while I'm sorry you haven't seen improvements - this fact can not be used to judge the economy. even if you know five other people who feel the same.

if you want to challenge your conception- check how many people around have new phones? how many new businesses have opened in your area? how many trucks with "drivers wanted" you can see on the road. In the vast majority of places (not all) you will see how mistaken you are..
But 2016 & 2017 will show a decline in rural income  given the drop in ag commodities prices.
both measures, not moth measures
None of it is true unless Donald says so.

I don't entirely understand your stream-of-consciousness dissertation of your theory, but to summarize:

(1) You have not actually read the Census Bureau's report, which is provided as a link in this article. Otherwise, you would have known that the report explains its methodology and data source within the first few page.

(2) You have cited no evidence that contradicts the Census Bureau's information or supports your theory. You are just convinced the Census Bureau is lying.

What a fine example of America is the 21st century. Too lazy to read even the first few pages of a report a single click away, and prepared to believe conspiracy theories without evidence. No wonder Trump is on the cusp of becoming President.
Evidence, please?

It may come as a shock to you, but living in desirable places is expensive everywhere. It's the same in London. It's the same in Tokyo. That's been an unfortunate fact of life long before Obama took charge, and it's not an economic indicator. If you look at places like San Francisco and Portland, the population and median income is actually ticking upward. Rent's going up because more people with money are moving in.

In fact, the places where housing is affordable are the most economically depressed areas. Go to Buffalo or other rust belt towns, and you won't need rent control.

This is a hate-filled comment - "the Deplorables"? Are Clinton supporters really embracing this? it's ok with you to deny humanity to millions of people you don't even know? Imagine calling all Asians "the Deplorables," or all Muslims.

It's very depressing that this got the most likes. So upper class folks with jobs can despise lower class folks, they can be as hate-filed as they want to their heart's content--as long as their hatred is directed toward low income powerless white men (leaving aside women and non-whites are also rural), and as long as they get to paint them as contemptible "racists".

Low income white men are the new fatsos. And they can be despised with the same smug moral superiority.

This is nothing but class warfare disguised as righteousness.
Next few centuries? Try decades.

Once the conspiracy theory lovers get hold of... well... anything, you can expect them to make up any story that suits their agenda.

Here's a dare for you:
Next time you drive, count the amount of trucks with "drivers wanted" signs.

Or maybe you'll blame the government for putting these there?
unlike the Bush administration, which of course had nothing to do with what happened at the exact same time right years ago.
Excellent comment, Eugene. My thoughts almost exactly in the last paragraph.
Still no reason to vote for Billary, tony.
I'm sorry. This sounds like a Monty Python sketch. I can't believe someone put so much time and effort into writing something like this for public mockery.

You did in fact confuse income and inflation. Social Security is raised based on a basket of goods. Some have gone up, most have stagnated or gone down. Energy, food, travel, electronics have all not increased.
It might feel to you differently, and it may even be truly different in your area.
That does not change the fact that nationaly inflation is actively too low. And while social security is a difficult issue that should be addresses, current lackluster rises have nothing to do with what you wrote.

Additionally, you are welcome to read detailed description of all the methodology used by the Bureau of Statistics.
Once you have, let us know if you find mistakes. Until then, your conspiracy theories are just that.

This remarkable recovery (when compared to other countries or the great depression) has produced a striking list of positive indicators. Job growths, investment figures, nascent industries.. and now rising wages. If you think about it, fallowing a gigantic wave of unemployment(with many workers) it takes time to get to a point where enough are hired again to create a competition for workers - increasing wages.

Lastly, if you refuse to believe data when it doesn't suite your predisposed opinion, don't use it when it does. For example, don't state the last few years were bad, bases on the same parameters you are no questioning. That's just hypocritical.
Did you read that somewhere, DLP? Because my own and a lot of other people's real-life experience in food shopping, paying utilities, etc. says otherwise.
There was no CoLA in 2016, and the CoLA for 2017 is set to be $2.50/month. Yuuuge, right? Not to mention Medicare is going up around $20/month. Good times.

The report is direct from the Census Bureau, American Community Survey.

Are you arguing that the hundreds of quant PhDs employed by the U.S. Census are unable to make the correct computations? I find that hard to believe.
Would you be happier if incomes had gone down?
